heading: Title
text: Exploring Nature's Solutions: A Guide to Bio-Inspired Optimization Techniques

heading: Abstract
text: Bio-inspired optimization algorithms are highly effective in solving complex optimization problems. These algorithms are inspired by the principles of natural biological evolution and the collective behavior of living organisms such as insects and animals. Compared to other classical techniques, bio-inspired optimization algorithms exhibit diverse, robust, dynamic, complex, and fascinating phenomena. This paper provides an overview of the taxonomy of bio-inspired optimization algorithms based on the biological field that inspired them and the areas where they have been successfully applied.

heading: Introduction
text: Bio-inspired algorithms have become increasingly popular in recent years due to their ability to solve complex optimization problems. These algorithms are broadly classified into three categories: evolutionary-based, swarm-based, and ecology-based. Evolutionary-based algorithms simulate natural biological evolution and social behavior to find optimal solutions to large-scale optimization problems. Swarm-based algorithms are inspired by the behaviors of social living beings in nature, such as ants, birds, and bees, and are designed to achieve specific goals through cooperation. Ecology-based algorithms use ecological concepts to develop cooperative search algorithms. These algorithms have been successfully applied in various fields, including computer science. Some of the most well-known bio-inspired optimization algorithms include Ant Colony Optimization, Particle Swarm Optimization, Biogeography-Based Optimization, Artificial Bee Colony Algorithm, and Elephant Herding Optimization.

heading: Bio-Inspired Algorithms (Bias) Taxonomy
text: Real-world optimization problems are often very difficult to solve and involve multi-objective optimization. Traditional deterministic algorithms cannot solve most of these problems, which are NP-hard. Bio-Inspired algorithms have been confirmed to be excellent methods to address these complex optimization problems, and have been applied to solve many such problems belonging to different domains. Various Bio-Inspired Algorithms have been developed, taking inspiration from different biological swarms that occur in nature. The performance of many global optimization techniques, such as genetic algorithms (GA) is dependent mainly on the evolutionary settings of these algorithms. Generally, an effective Optimization algorithm should minimize time, cost, and effort for solving complex optimization problems, handle non-differentiable, nonlinear and multimodal cost functions, be parallelizable to cope with computation-intensive cost functions, have good convergence properties, and be easy to use.

heading: Evolutionary Algorithms (Ea)
text: Evolutionary algorithms (EAs) are widely used in science and real-time applications to find optimal solutions for complex problems. These algorithms simulate natural biological evolution and social behavior of living species. EAs include Differential Evolution, Evolutionary Strategy, Genetic Algorithm, Genetic Programming, and Granular Agent Evolutionary Algorithm. These algorithms are the most well-known and established among nature-inspired algorithms.

heading: Genetic Algorithm (Ga)
text: Genetic algorithms are a type of artificial intelligence that use principles of genetics and evolution to solve optimization and search problems. They are part of a larger class of evolutionary algorithms that mimic natural selection and recombination. Genetic algorithms create a population of initial individuals called chromosomes, which represent potential solutions to the problem at hand. By applying recombination techniques such as crossover and mutation, they attempt to find the optimal solution. Genetic algorithms have been successfully applied to a variety of fields, including mathematics, engineering, economics, and more. The procedure for how genetic algorithms work is shown in Figure 2.

heading: Evolutionary Strategy Es
text: Evolution Strategy (ES) is a computer science optimization technique that uses evolution and adaptation to evolve individuals through mutation and recombination. ES algorithms are designed to solve problems in the real-value domain and use self-adaptation to adjust control parameters of the search. Figure (3) shows how the Evolution Strategy Algorithm works.

heading: Swarm Intelligence Si
text: Swarm Intelligence (SI) is a fascinating field that uses the behavior of real living swarms to solve complex optimization problems. It is a part of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and was introduced in 1989 by Jing Wang and Gerardo Beni. The goal of SI is to design well-organized computational intelligent interactive multi-agent systems that cooperate to achieve a specific goal. By studying the behavior of birds, fish, and ants, SI algorithms can be used to control robotic swarms. This technology has the potential to revolutionize many industries, including agriculture, transportation, and manufacturing. With the help of SI, we can solve complex problems more efficiently and effectively than ever before.

heading: Ant Colony Optimization Aco
text: The Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) Algorithm is a clever way to find the shortest path between a starting point and a food source. This algorithm is based on the behavior of real ants, which are intelligent insects that live and work together in colonies. Ants communicate with each other through a chemical substance called pheromone trails. In the ACO algorithm, each ant randomly lays down a pheromone trail as it searches for food. If an ant finds food, it follows the pheromone trail back to the nest, leaving a stronger trail behind. Other ants then follow this stronger trail to the food source. This algorithm is a great example of how we can learn from nature to solve complex problems.

heading: Particle Swarm Optimization Pso
text: The Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm is a useful tool for solving computational problems. It is based on the social behavior of organisms such as fishing, schooling, and bird flocking. PSO particles work together as a group to achieve their goal. This algorithm is widely used to solve optimization problems and NP-Hard problems like the Travelling Salesman Problem (TSP). Figure (5) illustrates the process of how the PSO algorithm works.

heading: Elephant Herding Optimization Eho
text: The Elephant herding optimization (EHO) algorithm is a highly effective method for solving optimization problems. It is based on the herding behavior of real elephants in nature, where subgroups known as clans move under the leadership of a matriarch. Male calves that reach adulthood leave the clan they belong to. The EHO algorithm is modeled after this behavior and has been shown to be highly effective in solving optimization problems. Figure (6) shows the procedure for how the algorithm works. Overall, the EHO algorithm is a powerful tool for solving complex optimization problems and is based on the natural behavior of elephants in the wild.

heading: Ecological-Inspired Algorithm Eco
text: Natural ecosystems offer a valuable resource for solving complex computer science problems. These ecosystems consist of living organisms and their abiotic environment, including soil, air, and water. The interactions between species within an ecosystem can be intricate and multifaceted. Ecological-inspired algorithms (ECOs) utilize these interactions to create intelligent and cooperative algorithms. ECOs rely on populations of individuals, each of which follows a specific search strategy. Through diversification and intensification mechanisms, individuals within each population are modified to optimize the search strategy. This approach draws inspiration from ecological concepts such as habitats, ecological relationships, and ecological successions. By leveraging the power of natural ecosystems, ECOs offer a promising approach to solving complex computer science problems.

heading: Biogeography Based Optimization Bbo
text: Biogeography-Based Optimization (BBO) Algorithm is a global optimization algorithm inspired by the migration strategy of animals or other species. It uses the idea of the immigration and emigration of species between habitats to solve optimization problems. In BBO, each habitat is considered as an individual and has its habitat suitability index (HSI) to show the efficiency of individual. High-HSI habitat denotes a good solution and low-HSI habitat denotes a poor solution. Solution features emigrate from high-HSI habitats to low-HSI habitats. BBO is a population-based algorithm in which a population of candidate solutions is used for solving a global optimization problem. Applications that use these ideas allow information sharing between candidate solutions.

heading: Ps2O Algorithm
text: PS 2 O is an advanced optimization method that incorporates the concept of symbiosis between different species. This approach is based on the natural co-evolution of species in ecosystems and their interactions. The PS 2 O algorithm is an extension of the basic PSO algorithm and is designed to improve its performance. The algorithm is shown in Figure (8) and involves the use of multiple species to optimize the solution. This approach has been shown to be effective in solving complex optimization problems and has been used in various applications. Overall, PS 2 O is a powerful optimization method that can help to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of optimization algorithms.

heading: Conclusion
text: Bio-inspired algorithms are highly effective in solving complex combinatorial optimization problems. These algorithms are classified into three main categories: Swarm based algorithms, Evolutionary based Algorithms and Ecological based Algorithms. These algorithms have been successfully applied in various fields, making them a popular choice for optimization problems.
